Name: Aramo Grade 1 Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural
Review: ong>A sweetly balanced, refreshingly complex dried-in-the-fruit coffee, versatile and agreeable.

Name: Colombia Guadalupe
Review: ong>Quietly unusual cup with its foresty suggestions of dusk flowers and fresh wet wood.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe “Mini-Me” 2014
Review: ong>Big, balanced structure supports an exhilarating range and depth of aroma and flavor. A Yirgacheffe as strong as it is graceful.

Name: Orion Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Complex straight shot, but may be at its best in cappuccino and short milk beverages.

Name: Guatemala Finca Santa Isabel
Review: ong>Fresh, sweet, gently spicy wood notes complicated by lily and peach should please those who prefer to be coddled rather than jolted awake by their morning cup.

Name: Borena Ethiopia
Review: ong>A particularly spicy and rich version of the great Yirgacheffe profile; sounds like the holidays to us.
Coffee Origin: Borena Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, souther Ethiopia.

Name: Bliss of Gayo
Review: ong>A deeply sweet version of the great Sumatra profile; the famous earth notes here come across as moist pipe tobacco supporting lavish floral and a soft, banana-like fruit.
Coffee Origin: Gayo growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: San Formosan Estate
Review: ong>Taiwanese who want to support the production of their own local specialty coffee, curious aficionados from other countries, and anyone who enjoys a gently spicy, sweet-toned cup.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Tegu
Review: ong>Those who value both balance and intensity in a quietly distinctive Kenya.

Name: Konga Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the soaring and intense Yirgacheffe aromatic fireworks full on; in fact, full tilt.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kona Extra Fancy
Review: ong>Slightly darkish medium roast develops the chocolate in a round, deep, plump-bodied version of the Kona cup.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawaii.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Konga
Review: ong>Exhilarating range of sensation in this moderately dark-roasted Yirgacheffe, ranging from perfumy lilac to juniper-like pungency.

Name: Panama Los Lajones Bambu Geisha
Review: ong>Anyone who can afford this soaringly complex yet perfectly structured cup. Brew this precious coffee carefully.

Name: Kenya Githembe AA
Review: ong>Delicately, refreshingly brisk yet sweetly floral version of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Espresso Strata
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big-bodied straight shots and milk drinks. Should be able to wave the flag for coffee even in tall, syrupy milk drinks.

Name: Arabica Wild Kopi Luwak
Review: ong>True, Kopi Luwak is a novelty splurge, but if you want to splurge on a sensitively roasted version of this novelty with characteristically rounded acidity and authentically deep, fruity and musky/mushroomy aroma and flavor this version is a good choice, a choice that furthermore supports a good cause.

Name: Love Letter for Winter Holiday
Review: ong>Those who enjoy delicately brisk beverages with subtle, sweetly pungent aromatics.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Those holiday blend buyers who value a lighter roasted coffee that emphasizes with elegance and tact the honey, floral and cocoa side of the holiday culinary myth.

Name: Sumatra Aceh Takengon
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the newer refined style of Sumatra: deep, exotic, but balanced.

Name: Original Christmas, Nicks Holiday Favorite, Organic
Review: ong>Holidays for sure here: fruit, spice, brandy, big body.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>The out-front and expressive fruit, brandy and flowers that dominate cup and aroma should make a nice fit with holiday brunches and desserts.
Coffee Origin: Central Valley growing region, Costa Rica; Huila Province, Colombia.

Name: Panama Finca La Mula Geisha Natural
Review: ong>The aromatic fireworks are crisp and balanced in this version of the celebrated Gesha profile. The clean dried-in-the-fruit processing contributes a delightfully refreshing apple cider note.

Name: Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Superb balance, complete structure and deeply expressed aroma and flavor should impress aficionados while seducing any casual coffee drinkers around the holiday table.
Coffee Origin: Central Kenya; Toraja growing region, southwestern Sulawesi, Indonesia.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Idido
Review: ong>An aficionado’s essay in the pleasures of big, resonant, lavishly sweet acidity and simple but deeply expressed aroma and flavor.

Name: Panama Gesha Perci Red
Review: ong>An amazing coffee, with an immense range and depth of sensation.

Name: Kikai Kenya
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the deep, richly pungent, fruit-toned but slightly savory side of the Kenya profile. Lovers of big, complexly balanced red table wines may be particularly good candidates for this coffee.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Dolok Sanggul
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a complex, rather exotic cup dominated by molasses-like sweetness, tropical fruit and a hint of spice.
Coffee Origin: Dolok Sanggul, Lintong growing area, northern Sumatra, Indonesia

Name: El Salvador Finca Malacara Lot B
Review: ong>A light roast develops a sweet yet crisply drying cup with delicate, unusual aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana region, El Salvador.

Name: Real Inspiration Blend
Review: ong>This roundly deep, chocolaty blend should provide considerable rich winter inspiration.

Name: S.O. Espresso Mexico Santa Teresa
Review: ong>Impressive balance and layered complexity in this quiet but authoritative single-origin espresso should please those who take their espresso as straight shot or in short milk.

Name: Lycello Panama Gesha
Review: ong>Precious, delicate, refined, with a quietly layered complexity.

Name: Kenya Gichuka AA
Review: ong>Richly floral variant on the great Kenya profile offers complex structure, big but balanced acidity, plush mouthfeel.

Name: Kimel Papua New Guinea Peaberry
Review: ong>Those aficionados and others interested in sampling the roundly pungent fruit and rich coherence of a classic Papua New Guinea cup.
Coffee Origin: Wahgi Valley, central Papua New Guinea.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffee Konga
Review: ong>Fine and distinctive version of the newer dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia style, with a slight shimmer of ferment enlivening a richly and cleanly floral- and cacao-toned cup.
Coffee Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Mini-Me
Review: ong>Superb variant on the great Yirgacheffe cup: deep, resonant, exotic.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>This gently bright and lively espresso should particularly please high-note purists, though everyone should enjoy its sweetness, balance and understated, graceful complexity.

Name: Kenya French Mission Oreti Estate
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a crisply dry but complexly juicy, fruit-toned cup.

Name: Ethiopia Kelenso Mokanisa
Review: ong>Unusually deep and syrupy expression of the southern Ethiopian floral cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ganesha Espresso
Review: ong>A fine, versatile espresso, full and complex as a straight shot and delicately lively in short milk.

Name: Guatemala Finca Bourbon Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth and savory-sweet resonance in a classic Guatemala cup.

Name: Kagomoini Kenya
Review: ong>Briskly juicy, pleasingly syrupy Kenya.

Name: Tanzania Songea Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a gently bittersweet cup with unusual, engaging aromatics.

Name: Lennette Kenya
Review: ong>An exotic yet elegantly balanced Kenya, sweetly dry, lush yet restrained. Impressive and original.

Name: Lakeshore Blend Medium Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a gracefully balanced, refreshing cup with quiet aromatic intrigue.

Name: Sumatra Samosir Batak Medium Roast
Review: ong>A fine traditional-style darker-roasted Sumatra for those who enjoy the hearty but nuanced earth, smoke and chocolate of the style.

Name: Daybreak Morning Blend Light Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a gentle morning cup, low in acidity, balanced, unassuming and agreeable in character and aromatics.

Name: Mocha Java Medium Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy history and hearty coffee with a deep, savory complexity.

Name: Single Origin Arabica Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy pungent sweetness with a roasty edge in a darker roasted espresso.

Name: Kenya AA Gakuyuni
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the juxtaposition of berry and chocolate sweetness and tart, dry elegance of a fine Kenya.

Name: Yemen Haraaz-Red Marqaha Grade A
Review: ong>Those interested in the taste of history; I suspect this is about how the best of the “Mocha” coffees of Yemen tasted when they first arrived in Europe to establish coffee as a luxury beverage, though they were probably brought to a darker roast. Those who enjoy the more spicy-sweet, savory side of coffee may enjoy this selection regardless of history.
Coffee Origin: Haraz (also spelled Haraaz) growing region, north-central Yemen

Name: Sidamo Natural Micro-Lot Reserve
Review: ong>Unusually bright and citrusy version of the dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia cup should please classicists.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Natural Process
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quiet, cleanly understated version of the gently fermenty, dried-in-the-fruit cup.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A light roast develops the natural sweetness and crisp richness of this cleanly balanced dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: FTO Ethiopia Worka 3 Special Reserve
Review: ong>An outstanding version of the more brandy-like style of dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia coffees. The fermented notes are sweet, graceful and cleanly expressed.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere Natural
Review: ong>Clean but unusual profile for coffee adventurers.

Name: Ethiopia Aramo Natural
Review: ong>A lighter-roasted dried-in-the-fruit coffee that balances great purity and clarity of structure with delicately lush aromatics. Perhaps may satisfy those clean-cup fanatics willing to at least experiment with dried-in-the-fruit profiles.

Name: Nekisse Ethiopia Sidama
Review: ong>A nicely conducted extreme light roast develops the lyric sweetness and delicate complexity of this very pure dried-in-the-fruit coffee. Those who enjoy sophisticated lagers with floral-toned hops might be particular candidates for this one.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Banko Natural
Review: ong>Environmentally and socially conscious hedonists. A lush, voluptuous, but cleanly structured dried-in-the-fruit coffee with the chocolate, flowers and brandy appeal of the type plus Fair Trade and organic certifications.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Aricha
Review: ong>A hint of blueberry- and whisky-toned ferment complicates floral and chocolate aromatics, all supported by almost perfect structure. A striking value; one seldom sees a coffee this distinctive and distinguished at such a reasonable price.

Name: Ethiopia Ninety Plus Nekisse Red
Review: ong>For those who can afford it, a coffee flawlessly balanced and deeply exotic in its resonance and complexity.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Guatemala El Tambor
Review: ong>Classic Guatemala: soft without simplicity, perfectly balanced, enveloping chocolate and low-acid fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Harfusa FTO
Review: ong>Honey and almonds and silky, lyric mouthfeel in this fine certified variant on the great Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: 100% Kona
Review: ong>A classic Kona, quietly complete, gently seductive.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: 100% Kona (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A fine, classic Kona for Keurig owners.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain
Review: ong>A solid version of the celebrated Jamaica Blue Mountain profile, with good low-toned fruit and chocolate.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A quietly impressive version of this storied origin for Keurig owners.

Name: Kenya Gachombe
Review: ong>Those who value the pungently dry yet sweet berry character of a classic Kenya.
Coffee Origin: Baringo and Nakura Counties, central Kenya.

Name: Makwa Kenya Nyeri
Review: ong>An aficionado’s Kenya, striking in its grand, expressive acidity and dry berry and floral elegance.

Name: El Injerto Geisha
Review: ong>The Gesha aromatic fireworks in an unusually suave and balanced package.

Name: Panama Los Lajones Bambu Geisha Natural
Review: ong>Exhilarating Gesha fireworks in a brisk, silky cup.

Name: Juliette Red Ninety Plus Gesha Estate Panama
Review: ong>Superb structure, pungently deep but exhilarating aroma and flavor in this fine variation on the rare Panama Gesha profile.

Name: 100% Kona High Mountain Io Extra Fancy
Review: ong>A classic cup in a big, deeply and complexly expressed, lushly tart style suggested but seldom achieved by fine Konas.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, Hawaii.

Name: Honduras El Cielito Finca Las Brisas
Review: ong>Purity, balance and a quietly lively complexity in an impressive Central-America-style cup.

Name: Thanksgiving Blend 2013
Review: ong>Deep, complexly original blend echoes many of the Thanksgiving season’s sensory themes.

Name: Rwanda Abakundakawa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy an intense, savory-sweet, pungently berry-toned cup with an impressively syrupy mouthfeel.

Name: Sumatra Blue Batak Peaberry
Review: ong>Superb Sumatra: juicy yet richly earthy; distinctive but balanced.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Costa Rica Sonora Estate Honey Valencia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy classic coffees with an exotic edge.

Name: Panama Los Lajones Estate Lot 14
Review: ong>Crisp, exhilarating dried-in-the-fruit profile, with the sweet ferment suggestions refined and subtle.
Coffee Origin: Eastern slopes of Volcan Baru, western Panama.

Name: Ethiopia Tswana
Review: ong>Those who enjoy brisk, delicate coffees with exhilarating aromatics.

Name: Ethiopia Worka
Review: ong>A style of richly and sweetly fermenty dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” coffee that now seems almost old-fashioned, given the progress producers have made in reducing the fruit-ferment note in dried-in-the-fruit coffees. The salty or bitter finish that often mars such richly fermenty coffees is absent here, however, so if you know you like the style, this coffee is an outstanding choice.
Coffee Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Guatemala Finca San Jorge Maracaturra
Review: ong>Those who enjoy gently dry, nut-toned coffees; aficionados interested in sampling a nicely roasted permutation of an interesting hybrid variety.

Name: Wahana Estate Sumatra Longberry 2013 Microlot
Review: ong>Aficionados of unusual profiles and anyone who enjoys crisply sweet coffees with a distinct chocolate character.
Coffee Origin: Sidikalang growing district, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Organic Yirgacheffe Aylele
Review: ong>The great exhilaratingly floral and citrusy Yirgacheffe profile in a particularly balanced and complete rendition.

Name: Finca El Manzano Bourbon Natural El Salvador
Review: ong>A very clean, balanced dried-in-the-fruit profile, the only hint of ferment an elegantly restrained dry whisky note.
Coffee Origin: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador.

Name: 100% Kona Grown Brazilian Typica
Review: ong>Coffee antiquarians, who may want to sample a very old, traditional strain of Typica, the foundational variety upon which much of the world’s coffee production was originally based, as well those simply interested in a superb Kona cup that is both deeply lush yet suavely brisk.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, Hawaii.

Name: Perci N2 Ninety Plus Gesha Estates Panama
Review: ong>Balanced structure supports an extravagant variation on the great Gesha profile.

Name: Batista Natural Geisha
Review: ong>Those who spend large sums of money for exceptional teas may find particular value in this crisp, subtly balanced but extravagantly aromatic Gesha.

Name: Panama Finca Santa Teresa Honey Geisha
Review: ong>This striking coffee seems to reference the elegantly pungent berry and flowers of Kenya more than the perfume and citrus of the Ethiopia-derived Gesha. Maybe think of it as a Kenya-fied Gesha. No matter which sensory category we place it in, a very impressive coffee.

Name: Mexico Finca Kassandra Pacamara
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the Pacamara pleasure: depth, resonance, low-toned fruit and flowers, sweet with a slight savory edge.

Name: El Agulia Pacamara El Salvador
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the richness and depth of a fine Pacamara.

Name: Panama Gesha Ninety Plus Perci Red
Review: ong>For those who can afford it, an extraordinary coffee, perfectly structured, intricate and exotic in flavor and aroma.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Zelele
Review: ong>Briskly authoritative version of the great, aromatic Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Guatemala El Socorro Maracaturra
Review: ong>Fine structure and a particularly wide range of aroma/flavor notes both express and exhilaratingly transcend the classic Guatemala cup.

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga Karimikui Peaberry
Review: ong>Anyone who loves coffee; spectacularly complex aroma and flavor erupts from a complete, balanced structure.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Deri Kochoha
Review: ong>Those who enjoy complex, resonantly bittersweet beverages. A superbly structured coffee with intricate and surprising aroma/flavor notes, deeper-toned and more pungent than we typically associate with southern Ethiopia coffees.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ulos Batak Sumatra
Review: ong>A superb Sumatra in the newer style: deep, exotic but balanced, dry but juicy.

Name: Haraaz Red Maragaha
Review: ong>Unusual profile from a rarely imported origin will interest aficionados and casual coffee drinkers who enjoy sweetly tart fruit character but avoid aggressive acidity.
Coffee Origin: Haraz (also spelled Haraaz) growing region, north-central Yemen

Name: Guatemala Huehuetenango
Review: ong>A fine exemplar of the gently balanced, quietly seductive, Bourbon-influenced style of Guatemala.

Name: Zombie Desert 100% Organic Haitian Bleu
Review: ong>Those who enjoy pungently bracing medium-dark-roasted coffees and who want to help improve the difficult lives of small-holding Haitian farmers.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A Yirgacheffe-lover’s Yirgacheffe: briskly sweet, complex, floral, buoyant and exhilarating.

Name: Ichamara Kenya
Review: ong>The deep, rich side of the great Kenya profile.

Name: El Salvador El Manzano
Review: ong>Classicists who want a little more than classic. Superb, balanced structure with a bonus of deeply resonant, engaging aromatics.

Name: Pas De Deux
Review: ong>Tart but deeply rich, an espresso in the brighter style but resonant and syrupy enough to please traditionalists open to variety.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A glorious old-fashioned Yirgacheffe: lavishly soaring flowers, bracing citrus, crisp cacao. A coffee to wake one up in every respect.

Name: Guatemala Injerto Noble Age
Review: ong>Those who enjoy classic coffees driven by an intense but sweetly poised acidity.

Name: One Love Ethiopia Yirgacheffe (RealCup capsule)
Review: ong>A fine, balanced rendition of the great Yirgacheffe cup for owners of Keurig K-Cup and other compatible brewing devices.

Name: 100% Colombian (RealCup capsule)
Review: ong>Owners of Keurig K-Cup and other compatible brewing devices who enjoy a clean, classic, zesty yet sweetly caramelly cup.

Name: House Blend (RealCup capsule)
Review: ong>Owners of Keurig K-Cup and other compatible brewing devices who enjoy a naturally sweet, balanced, quietly rich cup.

Name: 100% Peruvian (RealCup capsule)
Review: ong>Owners of Keurig K-Cup and other compatible brewing devices who enjoy a delicate, balanced morning cup with a particularly fine finish.

Name: Donut Shop Blend (RealCup capsule)
Review: ong>Owners of Keurig K-Cup and other compatible brewing devices who enjoy a straightforward, traditional medium-roasted cup.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain (RealCup capsule)
Review: ong>A rich, rather roasty version of a famous coffee for owners of Keurig K-Cup and other compatible brewing devices.

Name: Panama Auromar Estate “Ironman” Geisha
Review: ong>Exhilarating, intense cup for aficionados who can afford it.

Name: Elida Estate Natural Typica and Catuai
Review: ong>Adventurers and those who have no issue with glorious excess.

Name: Costa Rica Sonora Estate Honey Bourbon
Review: ong>Discreet adventurers. Classically balanced structure, quietly exotic aromatics.

Name: Ethiopian Kochere Grade 1 Natural
Review: ong>Those who value a wide range of exotic nuance, from particularly fragrant aromatic wood to crisp cacao notes to a deeply spicy floral character.

Name: El Guapo Guatemala
Review: ong>An unusual profile for aficionados: brisk yet deep, lush yet savory.

Name: Ethiopian Kochere Grade 1 Washed
Review: ong>Those who enjoy intense but refined acidity and bright, layered complexity.

Name: Guatemala Organic Fair Trade
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth and low-toned resonance in a small-producer, Fair-Trade-certified coffee.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: Finca El Guatelon Pacamara
Review: ong>The briskly bittersweet, deeply savory character displayed by some Pacamaras is on impressive display here.

Name: El Durazno “The Peach” Antigua
Review: ong>An impressive rendition of the delicate chocolate and spice and sweetly balanced acidity for which Antiguas are famous.

Name: Guatemala Las Ilusiones
Review: ong>Full body and a fresh, aromatic cedar in a round-toned but lively cup.

Name: Guatemalan Batzchocola
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a lush, rather exotic fruit and florals cup with a crisp, drying edge. The price represents an excellent value for a distinctive coffee.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: Guatemala San Rafael Urias
Review: ong>Classic Antigua: delicately balanced in acidity and structure and gently saturated with flowers, honey and chocolate.

Name: Guatemala Injerto EI-04 Noble Age
Review: ong>Striking in the juxtaposition of sweetness and the dry authority of its complex fruit notes. Both bracing and seductive.

Name: Guatemala Finca Armenia Yellow Bourbon
Review: ong>Classically deep-toned, pungently chocolaty Huehuetenango for fans of the type and the style.

Name: Guatemala Covadonga Micro-Lot
Review: ong>A fine exemplar of the sweet lucidity of the celebrated Antigua cup.

Name: Guatemala Finca La Soledad
Review: ong>Balance without boredom in a roundly tart, well-structured cup.

Name: Guatemala Acatenango Gesha
Review: ong>Delicate yet astounding in its juicy, complex, floral sweetness. Brew this very expensive, very sensitive coffee carefully; in particular, avoid pouring the water too hot if you brew manually; target 200F or so. Should be fine in automatic filter drip machines, which typically brew at relatively low temperatures.

Name: Kenya Ruira Mchana Estate
Review: ong>This is a Kenya lovers’ coffee, startling and unique. Also a good place to start for those who are still unclear about the sensory drama associated with the best Kenyas.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo
Review: ong>A lush but cleanly crisp, balanced dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: Panama Lerida
Review: ong>Those who prefer subtlety and balance to brightness and power.
Coffee Origin: Boquete growing region, Chiriqui Province, western Panama.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Grade 1 Aricha
Review: ong>The extravagant lemon-and-flowers Yirgacheffe profile expresses itself here with considerable balance and crisp elegance.

Name: Costa Rica Finca Santa Rosa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy an intensely but elegantly bright, crisply complex cup in the classic high-grown Central America mode.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica

Name: El Salvador El Naranjo
Review: ong>hose who enjoy beverages in which natural sweetness is deepened by a discreet savory pungency.
Coffee Origin: El Naranjo growing region, El Salvador.

Name: OneCoffee Ethiopian (single-serve cup)
Review: ong>A fine, accessible Keurig-compatible version of the citrus and flowers cup for which Ethiopia is famous.

Name: OneCoffee Colombian (single-serve cup)
Review: ong>Keurig owners who enjoy a balanced, softly bright version of the classic Colombian cup.

Name: OneCoffee Sumatran (single-serve cup)
Review: ong>A quietly persuasive version of a low-acid Sumatra profile for Keurig owners. The pineapple-like fruit, pungent and juicy, is particularly attractive.

Name: Ramal FTO Mexican
Review: ong>A naturally sweet, comfortable coffee with an aromatic that shares the freshness of moist, fresh-cut wood with an appealing floral-toned caramel.

Name: Hawaii Ka’u Isla
Review: ong>Classic honey, aromatic fir, flowers and citrus notes on steroids; intense, juicy, complete.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, Big Island of Hawaii

Name: Hawaii Ka’u Blend
Review: ong>A balanced, softly bright cup in a satisfyingly classic, Kona-associated style.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, Big Island of Hawaii; other undisclosed origins.

Name: Ethiopia Awassa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy rich, complexly lush beverages: ports, for example, or sweet, malty dark beers.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Guatemala Huehuetenango Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a roundly tart Central America cup with a classic complement of aromatics.

Name: Honeyed Yellow Caturra
Review: ong>A unique and precious profile, breezy and meadowy in it floral character, crisply complete.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Zero Defect Lot
Review: ong>A combination of honeyish sweetness and crisp, dry mouthfeel should please lovers of complex white table wines.

Name: Costa Rica Aguilera Brothers Finca Le Licho Micro-Lot
Review: ong>Fine balance and superb finish in this summery, briskly sweet classic.
Coffee Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Colombia Valle del Cauca Cerro Azul Geisha AAA
Review: ong>Amazing coffee; a whole basket of fruit and a field of flowers. If you can handle the price go for it.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Grade 1
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the sweet, acidy brightness of a high-grown, light-roasted cup with an intense, original aromatic bonus.

Name: Ethiopia Michicha Ardi Natural
Review: ong>Wide range of aromatic intrigue in this very complex variation on the Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Cocafelol Honduras
Review: ong>A hint of spicy aromatic wood deepens and complicates a plush mouthfeel and sweet-toned, chocolaty aroma and flavor.

Name: Honduras La Cuchilla Farm
Review: ong>Those who enjoy briskly dry though full-flavored white wines.

Name: David Mancia Honduras
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a balance of almost candyish sweetness and tart citrus in a classic Central America cup.

Name: Honduras Catracha “Alfonso” Microlot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic cup with fine structure and a quietly complete set of aromatics: a little chocolate, a little citrus, a shimmer of flowers.

Name: Los Lirios Organic Honduras
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quietly classic breakfast cup, crisp and resonant.

Name: Finca El Puente Honduras
Review: ong>Gently tart acidity enlivens a suavely classic cup.
Coffee Origin: Marcala growing region, La Paz Department, Honduras.

Name: Honduras Montana Verde Pacas
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a deep, pungent variation on the classic Central America cup. The Bourbon heritage of the Pacas variety may account for some of the pungent depth of this rather distinctive profile.

Name: Direct Trade La Tortuga Honduras
Review: ong>Those who enjoy quiet subtlety, soft acidity, and a graceful finish in a classic Central America cup.

Name: Honduras Cerro Gacho
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a piney, slightly savory hint complicating a richly sweet, dark-chocolaty cup.

Name: San Juanillo Costa Rica
Review: ong>A superb and subtly exotic variation for those who love the pure, classic Central America cup.
Coffee Origin: San Juan, Naranjo growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Hawaiian Kona Pele Plantations
Review: ong>The seductive, silky softness of the best Konas boosted by an extraordinary light, shimmering acidity.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawaii.

Name: Nyala Kenya Peaberry
Review: ong>An extraordinary Kenya, original and intense yet accessible.

Name: Tatu Kenya Peaberry
Review: ong>A rich, savory-edged variation on the great Kenya profile.

Name: Ethiopia Kercha Naturally Processed Sidama
Review: ong>Those who prefer a crisp, elegantly floral version of the Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit profile to fruitier or more wine-toned versions of the type.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Virtuoso Espresso
Review: ong>This full, deep, pungently chocolaty espresso is a pleasing and well-designed alternative to the brighter, lighter-bodied espressos currently in vogue.

Name: Ethiopia Hachira
Review: ong>An original and thoroughly engaging variation on the Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” cup that introduces a crisp, savory-sweet intrigue to the fruit and flowers typical of the type.

Name: Cerro Paldo Tarrazu Costa Rica
Review: ong>Should appeal to coffee classicists who want just a hint of the lushly exotic in their classic Central America cup.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica

Name: Costa Rica Sonora Estate Natural Bourbon
Review: ong>A dried-in-the-fruit coffee that impressively balances crisp savory and lush fruit and floral tendencies.

Name: Kenya AA Top Lot A114
Review: ong>Simply a superb Kenya, with a sweetly soaring acidity and a dry, berryish elegance in aroma and flavor.

Name: Colombia San Agustin
Review: ong>Those who prefer a smooth, crisply nutty morning cup with hints of a fudgy chocolate and a gently backgrounded acidity.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Mchana Kenya Peaberry
Review: ong>One of the most quintessentially classic Kenyas we have cupped in a long time. If any coffee merits the term elegant this one does.

Name: La Minita Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicate but deep cup with aroma/flavor notes stretching from flowers to a buttery savory suggestion.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica

Name: Panama Lerida Estate Lot 9
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a strong-structured, aromatically complex classic cup.

Name: Iron Range Espresso
Review: ong>An authoritative and deep straight shot. Should perform well in almost any volume of hot frothed milk.

Name: Brasil Sitio Sao Gabriel
Review: ong>An outstanding choice for those coffee drinkers who look for a lively and quietly distinctive yet low-acid cup.

Name: Ristretto
Review: ong>In many respects a classic authoritative Italian-style short shot for Nespresso owners, deep with dark chocolate and aromatic cedar, although a very slight flat woodiness shadowed the shot produced by our samples.

Name: Cosi
Review: ong>A lively, cleanly refreshing straight shot for Nespresso owners; fades in longer milk but should show nicely with short milk in an espresso macchiato, for example.
Coffee Origin: East Africa; Central and South America.

Name: Espresso Delicato Rivo Pack
Review: ong>A pleasant, chocolate-toned straight shot and short-milk espresso.

Name: Verismo Espresso Guatemala Antigua Pod
Review: ong>A decent straight-shot or short-milk espresso in the gently bright style currently fashionable in some circles. The main fault was a woody suggestion that we charitably read as aromatic fir but that could just as well be read as a sign of staling.

Name: Verita
Review: ong>At best a solid Italian-style espresso in the lighter-roasted style; at worst full-bodied but aromatically empty.
Coffee Origin: Peru; Brazil; Ethiopia; Sumatra, Indonesia; Nicaragua.

Name: Espresso Intenso Rivo Pack
Review: ong>Those who enjoy darker roasted espressos. Should stand up to sweetener and longer milk.

Name: Verismo Espresso Roast Pod
Review: ong>Perhaps Starbucks will improve the freshness and delivery of this capsule version of its flagship espresso blend in the future, but based on this sample, consumers who enjoy the café version of Starbucks’ espresso will not find this pod version nearly as cleanly pungent and authoritatively roasty.

Name: Vigore
Review: ong>I can’t think of a likely constituency for an espresso as woody and astringent as this one, though sweetener may help a little.

Name: Costa Rica Finca El Quizarra White Honey
Review: ong>Those who prefer subtlety to show.

Name: Nantucket Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Those who, like generations of drinkers of this classic blend, enjoy its natural sweetness and quiet complexity.

Name: Donut Shop Coffee (Vue-Pack)
Review: ong>A quiet, round version of the classic American breakfast cup.

Name: S.O. Espresso Rwanda Rulindo
Review: ong>A satisfactory espresso in all respects, but particularly try it for the unusual and very intense flavor in the small cup, an espresso variation on the great Bourbon profiles of East and Central Africa.

Name: High Tide Organic Espresso
Review: ong>An authoritative straight shot with excellent body and complexity turns pleasingly sweet and seductive in short milk.

Name: S.O. Espresso Organic Sumatra Aceh
Review: ong>Sumatra-lovers who particularly enjoy the savory, spicy tendencies of their favorite coffee type. Nicely interpreted here as a single-origin espresso.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, far northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Ethiopia Ardi
Review: ong>A fine, elegant variation on the great southern Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Sidamo
Review: ong>Fine range of sensation in a brisk but juicy cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kangocho Kenya
Review: ong>Those who value skillfully light-roasted coffees with richly sweet but uncompromisingly bright acidity supporting a pure and gentle complexity.

Name: Costa Rica Rio Jorco El Llano Honey
Review: ong>Those who enjoy brisk floral-toned beverages that are delicate yet authoritative.

Name: Teodosa Moreno Honduras
Review: ong>Those who enjoy dry but complexly aromatic beverages.
Coffee Origin: El Cedral, Santa Barbara Department, Honduras.

Name: Deri Kochoha Ethiopian Sidamo
Review: ong>The particular genius of Ethiopia wet-processed coffees from the best mills and growing regions of southern Ethiopia is beautifully on display here: lavish floral sweetness grounded in crisp chocolate, bright, juicy acidity, silky mouthfeel.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Trio Espresso
Review: ong>A classic espresso in the newer style: medium-roasted, roundly bright, full but not heavy in mouthfeel, displaying balanced fruit and chocolate in milk.

Name: Deri Kochoha Espresso Ethiopia Sidamo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy crisp, brightly aromatic straight shots and complex, lively cappuccini.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gatomboya Mill
Review: ong>Bright acidity and rich floral character in a classic Kenya.

Name: Sheeva
Review: ong>Those likely to enjoy a fine and original variation on the great Ethiopian cup: brightly juicy, deeply complex.
Coffee Origin: Oromia and Yirgacheffe growing regions, Ethiopia.

Name: Bliss of Gayo (as espresso)
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the sweet-toned, aromatic earth notes of a traditional Sumatra in an espresso presentation.
Coffee Origin: Gayo growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Costa Rica Villa Sarchi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy pungent, cedary straight shots and delicate chocolate-toned short milk drinks.
Coffee Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Kemgin Ethiopia
Review: ong>The sweet flowers and tart fruit of Ethiopia on steroids; intense and exhilarating cup.
Coffee Origin: Nekempte District, Oromia Region, western Ethiopia.
